column1: While serving a sentence for a federal narcotics offense
column2: petitioner was summoned before a federal grand jury and asked questions concerning his crime
column3: particularly as to the persons involved with him and their activities in smuggling narcotics into this country from Europe.  He invoked his privilege against self-incrimination under the Fifth Amendment and refused to answer.  Acting pursuant to 18 U.S.C.  1406
column4: which grants immunity from prosecution to a witness compelled to testify before a grand jury
column5: the United States Attorney
column6: with the approval of the Attorney General
column7: obtained a court order directing petitioner to testify.  He again refused to do so
column8: and was adjudged guilty of criminal contempt.

column1: Held:  the conviction is sustained.  Pp.  364 U. S. 508-515.
1. The immunity provided by  1406 covers state
column2: as well as federal
column3: prosecutions.  P.  364 U. S. 510.

column2: 1406 is constitutional
column3: since the grant of immunity from state prosecution is necessary and proper to the more effective execution of the undoubted power of Congress to enact the narcotics laws.  Pp.  364 U. S. 510-512.

column1: 3. The grant of immunity from future state and federal prosecution was at least coextensive with petitioner's constitutional privilege against self-incrimination
column2: and it was not necessary that he be pardoned or granted amnesty covering the unserved portion of his sentence and his fine for the offense of which he had previously been convicted.  Pp.  364 U. S. 512-514.

column1: 4. Since the District Court provided that petitioner's sentence to two years' imprisonment for criminal contempt should be vacated if petitioner should purge himself of his contempt by appearing before the grand jury and answering the questions within 60 days from the date of the judgment
column2: and this Court construes the 60-day period as running from the effective date of this Court's

it is not necessary to pass on the questions whether the sentence was excessive or whether the conviction was invalid because the District Court did not advise petitioner of the extent of the immunity conferred by  1406.  Pp.  364 U. S. 514-515.
affirmed.

column1: An Arkansas statute requires every teacher
column2: as a condition of employment in a state supported school or college
column3: to file annually an affidavit listing without limitation every organization to which he has belonged or regularly contributed within the preceding five years.  Teachers in state supported schools and colleges are not covered by a civil service system
column4: they are hired on a year-to-year basis
column5: and they have no job security beyond the end of each school year.  The contracts of the teachers here involved were not renewed
column6: because they refused to file the required affidavits.

column2: because it deprives teachers of their right of associational freedom protected by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment from invasion by state action.  Pp.  364 U. S. 480-490.

column1: (a) There can be no doubt of the right of a State to investigate the competence and fitness of those whom it hires to teach in its schools.  P.  364 U. S. 485.
(b) To compel a teacher to disclose his every associational tie is to impair his right of free association
column2: a right closely allied to freedom of speech and a right which
column3: like free speech
column4: lies at the foundation of a free society.  Pp.  364 U. S. 485-487.

column1: (c) The unlimited and indiscriminate sweep of the statute here involved and its comprehensive interference with associational freedom go far beyond what might be justified in the exercise of the State's legitimate inquiry into the fitness and competence of its teachers.  Pp.  364 U. S. 487-490.

column3: reversed.

column1: For refusing to leave the section reserved for white people in a restaurant in a bus terminal
column2: petitioner
column3: a Negro interstate bus passenger
column4: was convicted in Virginia courts of violating a state statute making it a misdemeanor for any person ""without authority of law"" to remain upon the premises of another after having been forbidden to do so.  On appeal
column5: he contended that his conviction violated the Interstate Commerce Act and the Equal Protection
column6: Due Process and Commerce Clauses of the Federal Constitution; but his conviction was sustained by the State Supreme Court.  On petition for certiorari to this Court
column7: he raised only the constitutional questions.

column1: 1. Notwithstanding the fact that the petition for certiorari presented only the constitutional questions this Court will consider the statutory issue
column2: which involves essentially the same problem -- racial discrimination in interstate commerce.  P.  364 U. S. 457.

column1: 2. Under  216(d) of the Interstate Commerce Act
column2: which forbids any interstate common carrier by motor vehicle to subject any person to unjust discrimination
column3: petitioner had a federal right to remain in the white portion of the restaurant
column4: he was there ""under authority of law
column5: and it was error to affirm his conviction.  Pp.  364 U. S. 457-463.

column1: (a) When a bus carrier has volunteered to make terminal and restaurant facilities and services available to its interstate passengers as a regular part of their transportation
column2: and the terminal and restaurant have acquiesced and cooperated in this undertaking
column3: the terminal and restaurant must perform these services without discriminations prohibited by the Act.  Pp.  364 U. S. 457-461.

column1: (b) Although the courts below made no findings of fact
column2: the evidence in this case shows such a situation here.  Pp.  364 U. S. 461-463.

Negro citizens sued in a Federal District Court in Alabama for a declaratory judgment that an Act of the State Legislature changing the boundaries of the City of Tuskegee is unconstitutional and for an injunction against its enforcement.  They alleged that the Act alters the shape of Tuskegee from a square to an irregular 28-sided figure; that it would eliminate from the City all but four or five of its 400 Negro voters without eliminating any white voter; and that its effect was to deprive Negroes of their right to vote in Tuskegee elections on account of their race.  The District Court dismissed the complaint on the ground that it had no authority to declare the Act invalid or to change any boundaries of municipal corporations fixed by the State Legislature.
Held:  It erred in doing so
column2: since the allegations
column3: if proven
column4: would establish that the inevitable effect of the Act would be to deprive Negroes of their right to vote on account of their race
column5: contrary to the Fifteenth Amendment.  Pp.  364 U. S. 340-348.

column1: (a) Even the broad power of a State to fix the boundaries of its municipalities is limited by the Fifteenth Amendment
column2: which forbids a State to deprive any citizen of the right to vote because of his race.  Hunter v. Pittsburgh
column4: and related cases distinguished.  Pp.  364 U. S. 342-345.

column1: (b) A state statute which is alleged to have the inevitable effect of depriving Negroes of their right to vote in Tuskegee because of their race is not immune to attack simply because the mechanism employed by the Legislature is a ""political"" redefinition of municipal boundaries.  Colegrove v. Green
column3: distinguished.  Pp.   364 U. S. 346-348.

column2: reversed.

column1: Petitioner was convicted under 2 U.S.C.  192 for willful failure to comply with a subpoena of the House of Representatives commanding him to produce before one of its Subcommittees certain records of the Civil Rights Congress.  The evidence showed:  before issuance of the subpoena
column2: the Subcommittee had reason to believe that the Civil Rights Congress was a subversive organization
column3: and that petitioner was its Executive Secretary.  At the hearing
column4: the Chairman of the Subcommittee explained that Detroit is a vital defense area and that the purpose of the hearing was to investigate Communist activities there.  When asked whether he would produce the documents called for by the subpoena
column5: petitioner stated flatly that he would not.  Neither at the hearing nor at his trial did petitioner deny the existence of the records or his ability to produce them.  He based his refusal upon a claim of his privilege under the Fifth Amendment.

column1: Held:  the conviction is sustained.  Pp.  364 U. S. 373-383.
(a) The Government's proof at the trial established a prima facie case of willful refusal to comply with the subpoena
column2: and
column3: inasmuch as petitioner neither advised the Subcommittee that he was unable to produce the records nor attempted to introduce at his trial any evidence of his inability to produce them
column4: the trial court was justified in concluding and in charging the jury that the records called for by the subpoena were in existence and under petitioner's control at the time the subpoena was served upon him.  Pp.  364 U. S. 373-380.

column1: (b) The Fifth Amendment did not excuse petitioner from producing the records
column2: since records held in a representative
column3: rather than in a personal
column4: capacity cannot be the subject of the personal privilege against self-incrimination.  P.  364 U. S. 380.

column1: (c) The evidence was sufficient to show that the records called for by the subpoena were pertinent to the inquiry.  Pp.  364 U. S. 380-382.
(d) The subpoena was not so broad as to constitute an unreasonable search and seizure in violation of the Fourth Amendment.  Pp.  364 U. S. 382-383.

column2: affirmed.

column1: The Government sued respondents to recover civil damages under  26(b)(1) of the Surplus Property Act of 1944 for obtaining surplus government property by fraud.  Later it moved to file an amended complaint seeking instead to recover damages under  26(b)(2).  That motion was withdrawn
column2: and the Government filed a second amended complaint again seeking damages under  26(b)(1).  After trial
column3: the District Court awarded the Government damages under  26(b)(1).  Both sides appealed
column4: and the Court of Appeals affirmed.  While the appeal was pending
column5: the Government accepted from respondents promissory notes totalling the amount of the judgment
column6: and it released only its judgment liens in two counties.

column1: 1. By accepting payment of an amount equal to the judgment appealed from as inadequate and releasing only its judgment liens in two counties in the circumstances of this case
column2: the Government did not lose its right to press its claim for the full amount of the damages it believed to be due.  Pp.  364 U. S. 312-313.
and the claims asserted by the Government were not barred by the statute of limitations.  P.  364 U. S. 313.

column1: 3. In the circumstances of this case
column2: in which the issue was preserved in a pretrial order pursuant to Rule 16 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
column3: the Government did not waive its contention that it was entitled to change its election of remedies and to recover under  26(b)(2)

column1: 4. The Government's original complaint seeking damages under  26(b)(1) did not constitute an irrevocable election of remedies
column2: and
column3: in the circumstances of this case
column4: the Government had a right to amend its pleadings so as to seek damages under  26(b)(2).  Pp.  364 U. S. 316-317.

column1: 5. Section 26(b) did not empower the District Court to determine according to the evidence which of the three subsections would
be the most appropriate and to require the Government to accept judgment under that subsection.  P.  364 U. S. 317.
6. In the circumstances of this case
column2: respondents are not entitled to a new trial.  Pp.  364 U. S. 317-318.
reversed.

column1: 1. In this proceeding under  209(b) of the Interstate Commerce Act
column2: the Commission exceeded its statutory authority by granting to a motor carrier subsidiary of a railroad permits to act as a contract carrier for a single shipper from points on the railroad's line in California to points on its line in certain other States
column3: since the Commission neither (1) imposed conditions upon the permits sufficient to assure that the service to be rendered would be truly auxiliary to
column5: the rail service
column6: nor (2) made findings sufficient to establish the existence of ""special circumstances"" justifying the waiver of such restrictions.  Pp.  364 U. S. 3-15.

column1: (a) The general policy under  5(2)(b) and the National Transportation Policy of restricting the services of motor carrier subsidiaries of railroads to those which are auxiliary to
column2: or supplemental of
column3: the parent railroad's services is applicable to permits under  209(b).  Pp.  364 U. S. 6-7.

column1: (b) If a trucking service can fairly be characterized as auxiliary to
column2: or supplemental of
column3: train service
column4: there is compliance with the mandate of  5(2)(b) that the railroad should be able to ""use service by motor vehicle to public advantage in its operations""; but
column5: if the motor transportation is essentially unrelated to the rail service
column6: the parent railroad is invading the field of trucking
column7: and

column2: the National Transportation Policy is thereby offended.  Pp.  364 U. S. 7-9.

column1: (c) When there are ""special circumstances"" sufficient to justify such action in the public interest
column2: however
column3: the Commission may sometimes refrain from imposing the condition that the trucking service be auxiliary to
column5: the rail service.  American Trucking Associations v. United States

column1: (d) The conditions imposed upon the permits in this case were not sufficient to restrict the motor carrier to operations truly auxiliary to
column2: or supplemental of
column3: the rail service.  Pp.  364 U. S. 11-13.

column1: (e) The Commission's findings in this case were not sufficient to establish the existence of ""special circumstances"" justifying the waiver of such restrictions.  Pp.  364 U. S. 13-15.
2. Insofar as it pertains to the permits to serve points on the railroad's lines
column2: the judgment of the District Court denying relief is reversed
column3: and the case is remanded to the Commission for such further proceedings
column5: as may be appropriate.  Pp.  364 U. S. 15-17.

column2: however
column3: do not apply to the Commission's grant of authority to provide contract carrier service to three nonrail points in Nevada.  P.  364 U. S. 17.

column2: six motor carriers and three associations of motor carriers
column3: had standing to maintain their action to set aside the Commission's order
column4: under the ""party in interest"" criterion of  205(g) of the Interstate Commerce Act and under the ""person suffering legal wrong . . . or adversely affected or aggrieved"" criterion of 10(a) of the Administrative Procedure Act.  Pp.  364 U. S. 17-18

|364 u.s. 76|United States v. Cannelton Sewer Pipe Co.
The Internal Revenue Code of 1939 permitted taxpayers to deduct as a depletion allowance a percentage of ""gross income from mining
column2: and defined ""mining"" as including the

column1: ordinary treatment processes normally applied by mine owners . . . to obtain the commercially marketable mineral product or products.""
Respondent mines fire clay and shale for which there is a market
column2: but which it utilizes to manufacture sewer pipe and other vitrified articles.  It claims that it could not profitably market its raw fire clay and shale without processing them into finished products.

column1: Held:  Respondent's depletion allowance must be based
column2: not upon the value of the sewer pipe and other vitrified products which it manufactures
column3: but upon the value of its raw fire clay and shale after application of ordinary treatment processes normally applied in the recovery of those materials by miners not engaged in the manufacture of finished products.  Pp.  364 U. S. 77-90.

column1: (a) Congress intended to grant miners a depletion allowance based on the constructive income from the raw mineral product
column2: if marketable in that form
column3: and not on the value of finished articles.  Pp.  364 U. S. 81-86.

column1: (b) A depletion allowance is an allowance for the exhaustion of capital assets -- not a subsidy to manufacturers or to high-cost mine operators.  P.  364 U. S. 86.
(c) That respondent is both a miner and a manufacturer does not entitle it to treatment different from that accorded miners of the same raw materials who are not manufacturers.  Pp.  364 U. S. 86-88.

(d) That respondent's underground method of mining prevents it from selling its raw fire clay and shale does not entitle it to treatment different from that accorded to the other miners of the same raw materials.  Pp.  364 U. S. 88-89.

column1: 2. Without probable cause for arrest and without a warrant for search or arrest
column2: state police officers followed a taxicab in which petitioner was riding and approached it when it stopped at a traffic light.  The record is unclear as to the sequence of the events which followed
column3: but the cab door was opened
column4: petitioner dropped a recognizable package of narcotics to the floor of the vehicle
column5: and one officer grabbed the petitioner as he alighted from the cab and another officer retrieved the package.  In a state prosecution for unlawful possession of narcotics
column6: the evidence was suppressed on the ground that it had been unlawfully seized
column7: and petitioner was acquitted.  Later
column8: in a federal prosecution under 21 U.S.C.  174 for unlawful receipt and concealment of narcotics
column9: the Federal District Court denied a timely motion to suppress and admitted the package of narcotics in evidence
column10: and petitioner was convicted.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  the case is remanded to the District Court for determination as to the lawfulness of the state officers' conduct
column2: in accordance with the basic principles governing the validity of searches and seizures by federal officers under the Fourth Amendment
column3: and for other proceedings consistent with this opinion.  Pp.  364 U. S. 255-262.

column2: it cannot be said that there existed probable cause for an arrest when the officers decided to alight from their car and approach the taxicab in which petitioner was riding.  P.  364 U. S. 261.
if the arrest occurred when the officers took their positions at the doors of the taxicab
column3: nothing that happened thereafter could make the arrest lawful or justify a search as its incident.  Pp.  364 U. S. 261-262.

column1: (c) If the petitioner voluntarily revealed the package of narcotics to the officers' view
column2: a lawful arrest could then have been supported by reasonable cause to believe that a felony was being committed in their presence.  P.  364 U. S. 262.

column1: (d) The validity of the search turns upon the narrow question of when the arrest occurred

column1: Petitioner and two others were tried before a jury in a North Carolina state court on an indictment jointly charging them with robbery.  Petitioner
column2: who was 18 years old
column3: asked the judge to appoint a lawyer to help him in his defense
column4: stating that he was without funds to employ counsel and was incapable of defending himself; but this request was denied.  Counsel for one of petitioner's codefendants volunteered to help petitioner and the third defendant
column5: but
column6: in the midst of the trial and in the presence of the jury
column7: his client pleaded guilty to petit larceny
column8: that plea was accepted
column9: and the lawyer withdrew from the proceedings.  No steps were taken to protect petitioner from the potential prejudice resulting from the guilty plea of his codefendant in the presence of the jury
column10: and petitioner and his other codefendant were convicted of larceny from the person
column11: a felony under North Carolina law.

column1: Held:  the prejudicial position in which petitioner found himself when his codefendant pleaded guilty before the jury raised problems requiring professional knowledge and experience beyond a layman's ken

column1: |363 u.s. 202|"Pennsylvania Railroad Co. v. United States

A railroad sued in the Court of Claims to recover from the United States the difference between its ""domestic rates"" and its ""export rates"" on certain shipments of iron and steel intended for export but which actually were not exported because of war conditions.  The Court of Claims suspended proceedings to enable the parties to have the Interstate Commerce Commission pass on the reasonableness of the rates.  After hearings
column2: the Commission found and reported that the domestic rates were ""unjust and unreasonable"" as to 62 of the shipments but ""just and reasonable"" as to 13 of them.  The railroad then invoked the jurisdiction of a Federal District Court under 28 U.S.C.  1336
column3: 1398 and 49 U.S.C.  17(9) to enjoin and set aside the Commission's order
column4: and it moved that the Court of Claims stay its proceedings until the District Court could pass upon the validity of the order.

column3: affirmed.

column1: In order to meet the bid of a favored buyer
column2: a seller's broker reduced his brokerage commission from 5% to 3%
column3: which was reflected in the seller's reduction of the price of apple concentrate from $1.30 per gallon to $1.25 per gallon; the sale was consummated at that price; and similar concessions were granted on subsequent sales to the same buyer
column4: but not to any other buyer.

column1: Held:  the seller's broker violated  2(c) of the Clayton Act
column2: as amended by the Robinson-Patman Act
column3: which makes it unlawful for ""any person"" to make any allowance in lieu of ""brokerage"" to the ""other party to such transaction.""  Pp.  363 U. S. 167-177.

column1: (a) A seller's broker is included within the term ""any person"" as used in  2(c).  P.  363 U. S. 170.

(b) Such an allowance was not made lawful by the proviso of  2(a) which exempts from the prohibitions of that section price differentials based on savings in selling costs resulting from differing methods of distribution.  Pp.  363 U. S. 170-174.
(c) The fact that the buyer was not aware that its favored price was based in part on a discriminatory reduction in the broker's commission is immaterial.  Pp.  363 U. S. 174-175.
(d) Section 2(c) applies to payments or allowances by a seller's broker to a buyer
column2: whether made directly to the buyer or indirectly through the seller.  Pp.  363 U. S. 175-176.
reversed.

column2: but that of a friend who permitted him to use it

column5: and petitioner was arrested and charged with violating the narcotics laws.  He moved to suppress the evidence so seized on the ground that the search was illegal.  Held:  Petitioner was a ""person aggrieved"" within the meaning of Rule 41 (e) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure

a Federal District Court does not have jurisdiction of an action by a taxpayer for refund of a part payment made by him on an assessment for an alleged deficiency in his income tax.  The taxpayer must pay the full amount of the assessment before he may challenge its validity in an action under 1346(a)(1).  Flora v. United States

column1: (a) The language of  1346(a)(1) can more readily be construed to require payment of the full tax before suit than to permit suit for recovery of a part payment.  Pp.  362 U. S. 148-151.

(b) The legislative history of  1346(a)(1) is barren of any clue to the congressional intent on this issue; but that section is a jurisdictional provision which is a keystone in a carefully articulated and quite complicated structure of tax laws; since enactment of its precursor in 1921
column2: Congress has several times acted upon the assumption that  1346(a)(1) requires full payment before suit; and any evidence of a contrary intent is too weak and insubstantial to justify destroying the existing harmony of the tax statutes.  Pp.  362 U. S. 151-158.

column1: (c) In establishing the Board of Tax Appeals (now the Tax Court)
column2: Congress acted upon the assumption that full payment of the tax assessed was a condition precedent for bringing suit for refund in a District Court
column3: and it chose to establish the Board as a different forum where the validity of an assessment could be litigated without prior payment in full.  Pp.  362 U. S. 158-163.

column1: (d) To permit such a suit in a District Court would be inconsistent with the purpose of  405 of the Revenue Act of 1935
column2: which amended the Declaratory Judgment Act so as to except disputes ""with respect to Federal taxes.""  Pp.  362 U. S. 164-165.

column1: (e) To permit such a suit in a District Court would generate the very problems which Congress believed it had solved by  7422(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954.  Pp.  362 U. S. 165-167.
(f) A different conclusion is not required by the administrative practice prior to 1940
column2: nor by a few inconsequential exceptions to

column1: the otherwise uniform belief prior to 1940 that full payment had to precede suit in a District Court for refund.  Pp.  362 U. S. 167-175.
(g) Requiring taxpayers to pay assessments in full before suing in a District Court will not necessarily subject them to undue hardships
column2: since they may appeal to the Tax Court without first paying anything.  Pp.  362 U. S. 175-177.

column1: Appellants who are engaged in the business of growing
column2: packing and marketing Florida avocados in interstate commerce
column3: sued in a Federal District Court to enjoin appellees
column5: from enforcing  792 of the California Agricultural Code
column6: which prohibits the importation or sale in California of avocados containing less than 8% of oil by weight.  Appellants claimed that  792 violated the Commerce and Equal Protection Clauses of the Federal Constitution
column7: as well as the Federal Agricultural Marketing Agreement Act of 1937 and Florida Avocado Order No. 69 issued thereunder.  A three-judge District Court convened to hear the case dismissed the action
column8: and a direct appeal was taken to this Court.

column1: 1. Since the complaint sought an injunction against enforcement of the state statute on grounds of federal unconstitutionality
column2: the action was required to be heard by a three-judge District Court under 28 U.S.C.  2281
column3: and this Court has jurisdiction of this direct appeal under 28 U.S.C. 1253 -- notwithstanding the fact that the complaint also alleged that the state statute conflicted with the federal Act.  Pp.  362 U. S. 75-85.

column1: 2. In view of the allegation of the complaint that appellants have made more than a score of shipments of Florida avocados to California and that appellees have consistently condemned them for failure to contain 8% or more of oil by weight
column2: thus forcing appellants to reship them and sell them in other States to prevent their destruction and complete loss
column3: there is an existing dispute between the parties as to present legal rights amounting to a justiciable controversy; and the fact that appellants did not contest the validity of  792 or seek abatement of appellees' condemnation of the avocados in California state courts does not bar their right

column1: to seek an injunction in the federal courts against its enforcement on the ground that it violates both the Federal Constitution and the Federal Agricultural Marketing Agreement Act of 1937.  Pp.  362 U. S. 85-86.

|361 u.s. 376|Phillips Chemical Co. v. Dumas Independent School District
Under Art. 5248 of the Revised Civil Statutes of Texas
column2: as amended in 1950
column3: which pertains to taxation of private users of property of the United States
column4: a Texas School District assessed against appellant a tax measured by the full value of real property owned by the United States but leased to appellant for use in its private manufacturing business under a lease subject to termination at the option of the United States in the event of a national emergency or a sale of the property.  The Texas Supreme Court construed Art. 5248 as authorizing this assessment against appellant
column5: but it had construed Art. 7173
column6: which governs taxation of private lessees of real property owned by the State and its political subdivisions
column7: as not authorizing taxation of a lessee under a lease subject to termination at the lessor's option in the event of a sale.

column1: Held:  as construed and applied in this case
column2: Art. 5248 discriminates unconstitutionally against the United States and its lessees
column3: and the tax levied against appellant is invalid. Pp. 377-387.

column1: (a) Since Texas law authorizes taxation of lessees of federal property
column2: but not lessees of property of the State or one of its political subdivisions
column3: when the leases are subject to termination at the option of the lessors
column4: it discriminates against the United States and its lessees.  Pp.  361 U. S. 379-382.

column1: (b) Such discrimination between lessees of federal property and lessees of state property is not justified by any significant difference between them.  United States v. City of Detroit
column3: distinguished.  Pp.  361 U. S. 383-387.
reversed.

column2: after their importation but prior to their sale to ultimate purchasers
column3: labels reading ""Germany/USSR Occupied
column4: with intent to conceal the identity of the country of origin.  The District Court dismissed the information on the ground that removal of the labels did not violate  1304
column5: because the applicable regulation appeared to require the Soviet Zone marking for tariff purposes only
column6: rather than to apprise the ultimate purchasers of the place of origin
column7: and also that the regulation was not sufficiently clear and unambiguous to justify a criminal prosecution.  The Government appealed to the Court of Appeals

column10: the Court of Appeals certified the case to this Court.

column1: 1. The charges in the information are founded on  1304 and the regulations thereunder; the information was dismissed solely because its allegations did not state an offense under  1304
column2: as amplified by the regulations; the statute and regulations are so inextricably intertwined that an interpretation of the regulations necessarily is a construction of the statute

column1: On a complaint before the National Labor Relations Board charging that a union had refused to bargain in good faith with an employer in violation of  8(b)(3) of the National Labor Relations Act
column2: as amended
column3: it appeared that the union had conferred with the employer at the bargaining table for the purpose and with the desire of reaching an agreement on contract terms
column5: during the negotiations
column6: it had sponsored concerted on-the-job activities by its members of a harassing nature designed to interfere with the conduct of the employer's business
column7: for the avowed purpose of putting economic pressure on the employer to accede to the union's bargaining demands.

column1: Held:  Such tactics would not support a finding by the Board that the union had failed to bargain in good faith as required by  8(b)(3).  Pp.  361 U. S. 478-500.
(1) The basic premise of the duty of collective bargaining required in the Act is that it is a process in which the parties deal with each other in a serious
column2: good-faith desire to reach agreement and to enter into a contract ordering their industrial relationship.  Congress did not intend that the Board control the substantive terms of collective bargaining contracts through the administration of this requirement
column3: and it added  8(d) in the Taft-Hartley Act to make the proper construction of the duty clear.  Pp.  361 U. S. 483-487.

column1: (2) By adding  8(b)(3) to the Act through the Taft-Hartley amendments
column2: Congress intended to require of unions the same standard of good faith in collective bargaining that it had already required of employers.  P.  361 U. S. 487.

column1: (3) Section 8(b)(3) does not authorize the Board to infer a lack of good faith in bargaining on the part of a union solely because the union resorts to tactics designed to exert economic pressure during the negotiations.  Pp.  361 U. S. 488-490.
(4) The use of economic pressure is not inconsistent with the duty of bargaining in good faith
column2: and the Board is not empowered under  8(b)(3) to distinguish among various union economic

column1: weapons and to brand those here involved inconsistent with good faith collective bargaining.  Pp.  361 U. S. 490-496.
(a) A different conclusion is not required on the theory that a total strike is a concerted activity protected against employer interference by  7 and 8(a)(1) of the Act
column2: whereas the activity here involved is not a protected concerted activity.  Even if an activity is not protected against disciplinary action
column3: that does not necessarily mean that it amounts to a refusal to bargain in good faith.  Pp.  361 U. S. 492-495.

column1: (b) A different conclusion is not required on the theory that
column2: because an orthodox ""total"" strike is ""traditional
column3: its use must be taken as being consistent with  8(b)(3); whereas the tactics here involved are not ""traditional"" or ""normal
column4: and therefore need not be so viewed.  Pp.  361 U. S. 495-496.

column1: (5) To construe  8(b)(3) as authorizing the Board to act as an arbiter of the sort of economic weapons the parties can use in seeking to gain acceptance of their bargaining demands would inject the Board into the substantive aspects of the bargaining process to an extent that Congress did not intend and has not authorized.  Pp.  361 U. S. 496-500.

column3: affirmed.

column2: which disabled courts in actions under  17 from awarding ""unpaid minimum wages or unpaid overtime compensation or an additional equal amount as liquidated damages

column1: Basing her claim alternatively on unseaworthiness and on negligence
column2: petitioner brought this libel in admiralty to recover under the West Virginia Wrongful Death Act from the owner of a river barge for the death of an employee of an independent contractor engaged in repairing the barge
column3: who fell off the barge and drowned in navigable waters in West Virginia.  The District Court found that the vessel was unseaworthy and that the barge owner was negligent.  Basing liability on negligence
column4: it awarded petitioner the maximum amount of damages allowable under the West Virginia Wrongful Death Act.  The Court of Appeals reversed the District Court's finding of negligence and held that the vessel was not unseaworthy and that the decedent was not a person to whom the warranty of seaworthiness was owed; but it did not pass on the question whether unseaworthiness would
column5: in any event
column6: be available as a ground for recovery in a West Virginia wrongful death action involving a maritime tort.

column2: and the cause is remanded to the Court of Appeals to determine:  (a) whether the West Virginia Wrongful Death Act
column3: as to this maritime tort
column4: employs the West Virginia or the general maritime law concept of negligence; (b) whether
column5: in the light of that determination
column6: the District Court's finding as to negligence is correct under the proper substantive law
column7: and (c) whether the West Virginia Wrongful Death Act incorporates the doctrine of unseaworthiness in death actions involving maritime torts.  Pp.  361 U. S. 341-344.

column2: judgment vacated and cause remanded.

After having been discharged from the Armed Forces because of permanent mental disability
column2: and during an unauthorized absence from a Veterans' hospital where he had been classified as 100% ""incompetent
column3: petitioner was arrested on a charge of robbery.  After eight or nine hours of sustained interrogation in a small room which was at times filled with police officers
column4: he signed a confession written for him by a Deputy Sheriff.  Shortly thereafter
column5: he exhibited symptoms of insanity and
column6: after proceedings prescribed by state law
column7: he was found insane and committed to a state mental hospital.  Over four years later
column8: he was declared mentally competent to stand trial
column9: and was tried in a state court on the robbery charge.  His confession was admitted in evidence over his objection
column10: and he was convicted.

column1: Held:  the record clearly establishes that the confession most probably was not the product of any meaningful act of volition
column2: and its use in obtaining petitioner's conviction deprived him of his liberty without due process of law in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.  Pp.  361 U. S. 200-211.

column1: (a) Though it is possible that petitioner confessed during a period of complete mental competence
column2: the evidence here establishes the strongest probability that he was insane and incompetent at the time he allegedly confessed.  Pp.  361 U. S. 207-208.

column1: (b) On the record in this case
column2: there was not such a conflict in the evidence as to require this Court to accept the trial judge's conclusion that the confession was voluntary.  Pp.  361 U. S. 208-209.

column1: (c) Where the involuntariness of a confession is conclusively demonstrated at any stage of a trial
column2: the defendant is deprived of due process by its use in obtaining his conviction -- even though important evidence concerning the involuntariness of the confession was not introduced until after admission of the confession into evidence and the defendant's counsel did not request reconsideration of that ruling.  Pp.  361 U. S. 209-211.

column3: reversed.

column1: Petitioner was indicted and convicted in a Federal District Court for interfering with interstate commerce by extortion
column2: in violation of the Hobbs Act
column3: 18 U.S.C.  1951.  The only interstate commerce mentioned in the indictment was the importation into Pennsylvania of sand to be used in building a steel plant there
column4: but the trial judge permitted the introduction of evidence to show interference also with the exportation from Pennsylvania of steel to be manufactured in the new plant
column5: and he instructed the jury that it could base a conviction upon interference with either the importation of sand or the exportation of steel.

column1: Held:  The conviction is reversed.  Pp.  361 U. S. 213-219.
(a) Since the indictment did not charge interference with the exportation of steel from the State
column2: it was prejudicial error to submit to the jury the question whether the extortion interfered with the exportation of steel.  Pp.  361 U. S. 215-219.

column1: (b) The variance between pleading and proof here involved was not insignificant
column2: and may not be dismissed as harmless error
column3: because it deprived petitioner of his substantial right to be tried for a felony only on charges presented in an indictment returned by a grand jury.  Pp.  361 U. S. 217-218.

column1: (c) Since the jury might have based the conviction on a finding of interference with the exportation of steel
column2: the conviction must be reversed. P.  361 U. S. 219.
reversed.
